intro: Elaphoglossum gemmatum, commonly known as the gemmiferous holly fern, is a species of fern native to tropical regions of the Americas. It belongs to the family Dryopteridaceae and is characterized by its finely divided, lance-shaped fronds. The plant produces spores on the underside of its fertile leaves, which are typically clustered in small, rounded structures called sori. Elaphoglossum gemmatum thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in forest understories. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important component of its native ecosystems.
